item.title: Beogram 4002 RIAA Preamplifier: First Prototype Installed
item.description:
I was tasked with creating an internal RIAA preamplifier for a restored Beogram 4002 (5521). This addition makes sense since many modern receivers lack a dedicated phono input. Additionally, the pre-opamp RIAA preamps found in many vintage B&O receivers introduce more noise compared to modern low-noise audio op-amps. Researching contemporary RIAA preamp designs led me to the LM833 operational amplifier, a specialized low-noise op-amp for audio applications. I adapted a high-precision RIAA preamp circuit from a Texas Instruments application note AN-346, as established RIAA preamplifier designs exist...

item.title: Beogram 4002 RIAA Preamplifier: A New Power Supply Design
item.description:
This post follows up on my previous one about the RIAA preamplifier I’m building for a Beogram 4002 turntable. This preamp will allow the Beogram to connect directly to a modern amplifier’s AUX or TAPE input. While initially pleased with my prototype, I redesigned it for a cleaner layout and had it manufactured. The new boards arrived, and I assembled a preamplifier, thrilled with its appearance. item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Installation of Beolover Commander MkII Remote and Internal RIAA Pre-Amp Board
item.description:
The owner of the Beogram 4002 (5513) requested the installation of a 4002 Commander remote control and an internal RIAA pre-amplifier module. The Commander enables complete control of the 4002 using an Apple remote, while the RIAA provides a strong output signal, allowing direct connection to modern amplifiers via CD/DVD/AUX inputs.
